trustfund: TF023755-PHASE 4 WATER & SANITATION PROGRAM,TF020460-NORWEGIAN CONSULTANTS TRUST FUND,TF031714-BANGLADESH-URBAN DEVELOP. PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project was
            unsatisfactory. The key lessons learned include the
            following: Adequate resources should be made available for
            supervision. Institutional strengthening should receive more
            and explicit attention; this project is a prime example of
            how institutional weaknesses can seriously damage the
            quality of relatively simple physical works. The major
            problem facing the project was the government's
            inability to implement the agreed resettlement plan. More
            attention should be given to the institutional capacity of
            the local agency responsible for resettlement, and the plan
            should be formulated based on full participation of all the
            project affected people. In a country like Bangladesh which
            is prone to frequent natural disasters, there should be
            projects flexible enough to reallocate project funds for
            emergency assistance without having to go through
            time-consuming paper work. All the data needed for ex-post
            economic analysis should be part of the project's
            performance indicators. It is very important to help build
            institutional capacities of implementing agencies for
            effective monitoring and evaluation. Beneficiary
            participation is needed at every stage of development
            projects; government officials should be trained to improve
            their skills in community participation. Project size and
            complexity should be reduced, focusing on specific
            sub-sectors and numbering a few components that can be
            implemented by one or a few agencies.
